And then their friends all know that they have to go get their pill and then they're late to the lunch line and, you know, they just hate it. Recording: (1542/ 9621) 
 I was born in Dayton, Ohio. I lived there almost 35 years before moving to Columbus in 1981. I lived in northwest Columbus for 18 years. I moved last January a little farther west, about five miles further west near Hilliard, but still live in the city of Columbus. So I've been here about 18, 19 years. I like Columbus also. I think it's a great city, although the last three months I've threatened to move on more than one occasion because of all the traffic congestion and all of the road construction. You just can't get anywhere. It's very frustrating. But other than that, Columbus is a great city. I went to, this is something different about me. Most people don't know that it existed in the 20th century, but I went to an all-girl Catholic school for 12 years. So there were no boys, I wasn't in a classroom with boys until I got to college. I went to college at Wright State University. My parents couldn't afford to send me, so I had to work two years in high school, two years after high school to pay my way through college. Taught school for about eight and a half, nine years, and during that time got my master's degree in remedial reading. Taught for, I think I said this, about eight and a half, nine years, and my life and career took a whole different turn and became president of my teacher's association or teacher's union, and that led to a job in political action, because I'd always been active in politics from high school on. The first campaign I worked in was for John Kennedy in 1960. I was a freshman in high school and continued working in campaigns in a volunteer status, several different campaigns in Ohio and in Dayton where I came from, but moved to Columbus to take a job as a political action consultant for the largest public employee union. Did that for a couple of years until I went out in the field and negotiated labor contracts. Did that, that's kind of stressful. So I decided to strike off on my own and try some public relations and marketing and did that. I've never been married, didn't plan that, that wasn't a goal in life, it just never occurred. So I have no kids but I have a pet. And now I call myself semi-retired. I get a small monthly retirement and then I supplement my income by doing things like this. I'm an independent contractor. I do training, I do different things where people get my opinion. I've done a couple of things with lawyers looking, they do mock trials on real issues and then you listen to all of the stuff and then you, you know, pretend that you're a jury and come up with a decision. And I guess they use it in forming their case and going into court. So that's fun. So that's a little bit about me. I'd say my family, my mom and dad, well, my mother was first generation American. My grandparents came to this country from Hungary and that was a neat experience. I like growing up talking to my grandfather about what life was like as a peasant in Hungary. And he thought this was the greatest country in the world and that rubbed off on me. I still do also. He always voted so I learned at an early age that it's important to vote. My mom and dad were both alcoholics. I have two brothers, no sisters, one older than me, one younger than me. And I have no children, but I have a pet that is my child. And I always say pets are, children you raise, pets you spoil. So my pet is very spoiled.

I told them ignore the no votes. Just don't get them upset with you. You don't want them working actively against you. Lock up your 30 that are with you. Make sure you do something with them. So there's always people coming for four or five days and you have to explain everything in life to them in four or five days. And plus we lived in a rural setting where we did everything ourselves plus ran a restaurant and a hardware and had a mail route. And then we had all these visitors and then we made our own bread and we milked a cow. And so it's just plain hard physical work plus all the mental stuff of dealing with people's really big questions. It was intense. You know, so that's the reason I had to quit. It was like if I could leave this situation for a month or six weeks and get caught up within myself, I would have been okay, but that wasn't how it worked. So I had to pull back from it.

Recording: (6646/ 9621) 
 if they hold enough of my views. I'm not gonna vote for a woman just because they're a woman. And I'm not gonna vote for a Democrat just because they're a Democrat. They better have at least, and I don't need 100% agreement with my views, but I'd like to be it in the 90 to 95% range. But I don't tend to vote straight party line either. As I said, I've moderated from when I was in college to today, part of the aging process and also partly because I've noticed that to get things done, you have to have a center and it's the center that tends to rule. When I was in college, we had a bumper sticker that said America, fix it or forget it. And some of the construction people in Dayton came out with one that said, America, love it or leave it. And today I realize that both of those positions are wrong. It's America, love it and fix it. Just like with your kids, you love your kids, but you don't let them have bad manners at the table and you don't let them run around with the wrong kids and you want them to behave well. That's how I see America now. And America's become more centrist. And when it deviates from that either way, that's when people become upset. So I just think it's important. I remember when, who was the other president that I voted for that won? Carter. Black leaders would meet with him once a week and then they'd come out and hold this press conference and complain about he didn't do this for blacks and he didn't do that enough for blacks and he didn't do this and he didn't do that. And I used to say to some of my black friends, don't you see what you're doing? Don't you see the greater implications of this? Oh no, we need to have him move faster. I said, you know, that'd be great in an ideal world. This isn't an ideal world. You have to take it a step at a time whether you like it or not. I said, what you're going to do is you're going to make it look like he is so bad on all the issues, you're going to give people a reason to vote against him. Then if any big issue comes up, that's just going to be added to everything else. I said, what you need to do is after you have this meeting with him is come out and praise him and that he's doing a good job and that we're moving along steadily. And I don't think sometimes people who do politics of the negative understand what it means. I made that mistake when I was president of the Dayton Education Association. We were trying to get a levy passed. So we went around as teachers showing all of the bad conditions in the school, all of the leaking, you know, ceilings, all of the peeling floors, all of the bad chalkboards with cracks in them and all that kind of stuff. And it had the opposite effect of what we thought. People thought the schools were so bad, they said, we're not gonna support those. And they voted no. So the next time we did an opposite check, we went in and we said, 18 months later when the board put another levy on the ballot, we said, these are great schools, we have great teachers, look at this kid, he's learning to read, he's made six months improvement in three months and all that kind of, it was image, and we were saying the same thing, we wanna continue this, we wanna make even this better. We learn to say the negatives in a positive way and that's important, you know, and you need to get that, you need to appeal to the center. Americans don't like extreme liberals, they don't like extreme conservatives, you know, they want, they want peace.

So the frustrations with trying to find an adequate job and an adequate employer that understands my situation and how I operate and will give me freedom to do what I can do. I have a Bachelor of Arts in Communications but it's been more of a problem than it's been an asset. Interviewing for jobs, people that were doing the interviewing had just a high school education. And they're not gonna hire me when after a year I'd be their boss. So a lot of that is out there regardless of what people say. I'm not trying to be pessimistic or negative. It's just been my experience. Unfortunately, I hope it gets better. But like I said, I haven't been ever told that my degree matters by any employer. Contrary to what the news tells you and what people will tell you, oh, go get that college degree. People told me as soon as I got out of college that I needed a master's. And then they said, and after you get your master's, you'll definitely need your doctorate. Well, you know, the people saying this are college people. College is a business. And it takes a while to realize that. If you can get in and get that education on grant money and scholarships, that's good. But then even now, being a person with a semi-disability from a brain injury, I mean, I don't even like to call it a disability. I have different abilities now, same abilities I used to do, but I have to do them a different way. Just because my brain functions on a different level and I can't explain that to anybody and I shouldn't have to, but I'm always forced to. But trying to find a job, you know, resulting from this has been difficult. And I'm not giving up hope or nothing like that. I'm just trying to cut through and see what I can do. And there's just, it's very limited out there you know and your education is an asset but like I said even as a person now going through BVR I'm discriminated against in my opinion because I have a bachelor's. In other words, Bureau of Vocational Rehabilitation which is a government funded organization geared toward helping people with disabilities get back to work. And because I already have a bachelor's, they won't pay for school. Now if I were stupid, you know, if I just had a basic, just got out of grade school and didn't even have my GED, boy, they'd pay for my high school, my college and everything. You know, even living expenses, you know, but because I have a bachelor's, nothing, you know.

It's a rich man's person or a rich person's system. Judges are bought and paid for. They're elected. There's a lot of crap there and I learned all this not from just my experience but from people that I know that are attorneys. That there are judges down there that take bribes. And that's not right. So you can't, when you're dealing with that system, justice comes at a price and you get as much justice as you can afford. And during my lawsuit, that was very evident. You know, laws are made to protect people that are wealthy and that commit crimes. And it's not right. It's not fair, but that's the way it is. So I didn't want to go into law. Didn't want to go into paralegal. I was looking into that and lady kept pounding me and telling me, you know, maybe you could get in it to make a difference. I'm like, why would I want to make a difference if it kills me? You know, because I know myself and I don't put up with crap. I see a liar, I bring him out. I was just brought up to be an honest person. Unfortunately, there's a lot of people out there that they sell out their ideals and their principles for $40,000 a year. Then they use their family or their situation financially excuse to sell those ideals out. I'm not that kind of person and I won't ever be. So if that means that I stay monetarily poor for the rest of my life, then so be it. I got a conscience and people that are honest and have a conscience are dangerous out there. But that's basically where I've been. I've lived here my whole life, like I said. I went to college, I played baseball. Due to injuries, knees and shoulder, I was pro-caliber. I played baseball with Paul O'Neal and Kent Merker, which are a couple of guys that, you know, did get signed professionally and are playing right now. So at least I can say I played against him. And at least with Kent Merker, I can say I hit a home run off of him. So, that was a while ago, but it was when he was young and very good and I was still Can you tell me a little bit about what happened to Michelle and about your lawsuit? I don't follow that way anymore. I follow a more natural way of following God. Nothing new age. I don't want to say exactly what. I'm just saying that the people of this this land, long time ago before anybody came over here with their Bibles and crap, Raymond Jesus down in Peoples Third, the people of this land had a way of worshiping God, and that's the way I want to, that's the way I follow. So a lot of people say that's Native American, or say that's Indian, or whatever, you you know I don't care what they want to put on it, but it's It's it's a natural way of following God is the way I put it, you know Worshipping that and respecting the spirit that moves through all things all living things and So I went through all that and all those changes and are you know, coping with them and trying to find ways to cope with them too.

The lawsuit, we had a private investigator that went in there and found all the information that showed that they had all that higher, taller glass back there over a year. So they tried to use the excuse. Their excuse was that they couldn't find the hardware to install it. And given all the hardware stores that we have here and the ability to overnight freight things, if there was any kind of special hardware that needed to be ordered from out of state or out of the country, there's no excuse. So basically, it came down to a legal battle, which was I was not going to back down. I was poor monetarily, they knew that. So they were using the legal system to wear me down. The first, at the date of filing, I mean, first of all, it took, I had a statute of limitations, it was two years. I had an attorney and a law firm representing me, but they were dragging their feet. I felt they were dragging their feet because they were in bed with the chill. You know. And that they were getting paid under the table to drag their feet. Even though I knew the guy. So I just said, well look, I'm dissatisfied. I'm gonna go find another attorney. So give me my file. See ya. And I went shopping around for a new attorney. It took me about seven before, pardon me, seven attorneys before I found one that was adequate in terms of knowledge of head injury and brain injury because his father was a neurosurgeon and he had experience and expertise in bringing up the differences and the realities of a brain injury and the effects, the lifelong effects. So after the two years, we got in just under the two years. So I mean, hell that would be what it happened in 93. So just under December 95, the day, the last day of the statute running out, we filed. So we got it filed. Once it was filed, the judge scheduled a hearing and for whatever stupid reason, the soonest they could hear the case was one year from the date that we filed. So you can see when you get in to bed with, you know, and involved in the legal system in terms of filing a multi-million dollar lawsuit or whatever, you know, any kind of lawsuit, the big boys get all the breaks. So, in my opinion, the judge didn't want to hear the case before then, or maybe his docket was full, but I'm saying, you know, there's no prioritization in the legal system. There are some things that should be addressed soon. I shouldn't have to wait that long. So then, it came down to one week prior to the hearing, and I got a letter from my attorney, and he said that that and also a phone call from the office saying that That they Were filing a continuance Which meant that the judge granted them an additional year of discovery Whatever Whatever the law says, you know, the judge says he has to back it up. But, so I postponed the trial for another year, which pissed me off, you know. But that's exactly what they were planning on, you know, wearing me down, like I said. Knowing that I don't have the money to throw in there and say, hey, you know, um, but they know full well that we had all the evidence that we had to sell, uh, that just postponed it for another year. Finally, we got into, uh, coming in and then they, uh, sent a letter saying they wanted to meet for arbitration to see if we could hammer out some kind of settlement a couple months before the trial. I was unaware of this common practice, but it was a very iffy situation. Juries here in Columbus have been ultra conservative They feel that people for some reason or another That people that have been legitimately injured in their lives have been affected that they don't deserve money for whatever reason And I don't think it's fair that they can sit back and be that conservative if it hasn't happened to them. I don't think that's fair. Because it does affect your entire life. It has. Otherwise I'd be full-time employed. I'd be gainfully employed and making money and I'm not. And that's not because of anything. It's by choices on my part, but it's, you know, there's a lot there, the betrayal that I've had to struggle with, there's a lot there that, you know, I feel I've been betrayed by everybody that taught me. I feel betrayed by the government, by the legal system, by the politicians, by all the people that have been put in charge to protect people, to protect ideals, to protect principles, throw it out the window for money. And then when it comes down to me being legitimately hurt, it got down to just dollars and cents bartering for what my life was worth. And it's the bidding started at $125,000. Now I feel I'm worth more than that. I feel you can't put a value on a human life. There were just subtle things that my sense of taste and smell was gone for about a year and a half. Just all the trauma that goes along with it, not just the physical trauma, I mean, that was enough to kill anybody, but because of me, because of my size, because of my strength, I wasn't killed, you know. So the physical burden still remains. I was and is worse. Having to have a lack of money now means lack of socializing, means lack of going and doing things. Don't have a lot of relationships, don't have a girlfriend, don't have a wife, nothing like that. I've got a dog, a golden retriever,

And I don't yell and scream at them. I mean, I realize they didn't ask to have a learning disability. I mean, and they can't. Some teachers think they're just being belligerent, and if they want to straighten up, they could. And what I try to tell those teachers is they can't change their learning disability anymore, you can change your brown eyes. You know, they were born with it, it's genetic, someone else in their family has it. They can learn, they just don't learn the same way everybody else does. You have to break it down into pieces or teach it a different way. It's like teaching a math problem two different ways, you get the same answer but one way works better for you. Well, that's how they are. You know, maybe they don't learn well by listening. Maybe they don't learn well by looking at a chart or something. Maybe they only learn well when they're up moving around, doing something. You know, you just have to understand that their avenues of learning are like different than yours. And totally, some of them might be totally screwed up. Like they might hear half of what you say. Or they might jumble up what you say and you say, turn to page 393 here. And they turn to 339 in their book. And they think they did what you said. It's just like something's mixed up between the actual eye and the ear and then where it gets interpreted into the brain, it gets all scrambled somehow. And I always tell teachers if you could just walk for one day in their shoes, you'd probably have a lot of empathy for them.

Recording: (9046/ 9621) 
 and you register them and then you just keep after them. You keep giving them information and then you just run a good get out the vote campaign. In Ohio I think it's easier to do that because there is a law that I don't think it's in primaries but in general elections at 11 o'clock in the morning and 4 o'clock in the afternoon they have to list those who have voted. They have to put up a list of registered voters and cross out those who have voted. So what I used to do is I took my list that I had gotten from the Board of Elections earlier and compared it with my list of who had shown support or was undecided on the election, and I would cross off those that had voted, and then I had a list of those that hadn't, and I had people waiting at a phone bank, and I'd call them at work or at home, and I'd offer to take them to the polls. If you don't have a ride, we will take you to the polls. If you're worried about someone watching your kids, we have certified teachers who will sit in the car with your kid or will sit in your home and will babysit for you while you go to vote. Because I've also read studies that say people who are routed from their home or their office and are reminded to go, will also vote for whatever issue or candidate has reminded them to do that. Because what I did was, it's a very low key thing, I would call people on election day and say, hi, this is Roberta, I'm calling to remind you that today is election day, and we hope that you will remember to exercise your most important freedom, which is to go vote, and oh, by the way, when you go to vote, we hope that you will vote for such and such a school levy. And if you need a ride, let me know. We've got them set up for you. And but, you know, that's very I mean, and that's not getting people to vote and encourage them to vote because they should. That's a special campaign for a particular issue or a candidate. I don't know how you get people to vote. I don't know why they don't think it's important, maybe because we've had it too easy. My grandfather didn't. My grandfather didn't. I mean, there was a king and queen and he had no right to vote. So when he came here and he could, that was the most important thing in the world to him. And he just passed it on to his daughter, my mother, my father. I don't know how it was important to him, but it was always important to him. We talked about politics at the dinner table sometimes. We would say, grandpa, is it okay if we go out and clean your chicken house? Well, of course, you knew very well it was gonna be okay.
